moves.1. d4: This game comes to a sudden end when White overlooks a combination.
moves.3. Bg5: White should have taken the pawn instead. This move isn't bad, but simplifies things too much.
moves.3... exd4 4. Qxd4 Be7 5. Nc3 Nc6 6. Qe3: This move hampers White's development. Qd3 would have been wiser, and White could answer Nb4 with Qd2.
moves.8. Nd5 Nxd5 9. cxd5 Bxg5 10. Nxg5 Ne5 11: White intends to develop his bishop to g2, but the bishop will be blocked in by the pawn on d5.
moves.11... h6 12. Nf3 Re8 13. Bg2 Qf6 14. O-O: Black still needs to keep an eye on his weak queenside pawns.
moves.17. e4 c6: Black moves the pawn before White can threaten it with Rec1.
moves.18. dxc6 bxc6 19. Rac1 c5: Black has a backwards d-pawn, but it can be easily defended, and after all, it is an extra pawn.
moves.20. Rcd1 a5 21. Rd5: White blunders. His back rank is completely undefended.
moves.21... Qxd5 22. exd5 Rxe1+: Black already has enough material for the queen in the form of two rooks, but he's not done; he can win back the queen.
moves.24. Qd3 Rxf1+ 25. Qxf1 Bxf1 26. Kxf1 Re8: Now that the king can't cross the e-file, all Black has to do is push his c pawn.
